What is your overall assessment of this course
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning
I received clear feedback that improved my learning

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain
Comments_List: I learned a lot about how research translates to medicine. This occurs at multiple levels including data acquisition, processing, and implementation.
learned more about EPIC and Genomic resources
By taking this course, I have a broad overview of bioinformatics.

As a computational biology student, this course helps me gain insights into how informatics is applied in the clinical setting. In particular, I learned a lot about EHR and decision making, which will be valuable for my future research. Besides, through this course I understood the process of the clinical translation of the basic finding. These are two most import knowledge I learned from the class.
Clinical usage of some genetics, some clinical term, standards, procedures.
I have learned how to integrate clinical information into my research project.

I received a comprehensive review of medical informatics and bioinformatics, as well as many live examples of applications in actual clinical settings. These provide many novel ideas on how to translate biological knowledge into medical use.
The fundamentals of clinical informatics.
Knowledge about different biomedical datasets and corresponding analysis methods
I learned a lot about the medical side of informatics-- particularly, how doctors actually utilize the systems discussed in the class and why.

I think the large difference in students taking the course led to most of its weaknesses. Having clinical and PhD individuals together is a good idea as these topics are relevant to both, but I feel the lectures should have a specific audience in mind (one group or the other).

Strengths: variety of lecturers with different areas of expertise
Weaknesses: no in depth teaching on a specific topic as this course provided an overview of different topics
StrengthsMany guests in the field of bioinformatics are invited, which helps us to know what is going on or remains to be done in this field.

The course covers a great variety of topics that are helpful for beginners. However, because it is a required course for CBB students, it would be better if more contents relevant to bioinformatics are included.
Broad survey course is a strength.
It covers lots of clinical informatics topics.

The strengths largely lie in the variety of guest lecture faculty. The material could be a little dry and redundant. If the guest lectures were more evenly spaced throughout, it would make the course a bit more lively.
Yes, I think it is a good way to introduce many challenges in the field of medicine. However, I would recommend this course to clinically driven individuals and not bioinformatics individuals.
Sure. Especially for students in CBB, not only because it is one of our required courses, it also provides us with the big background of our future research.
Exam is not hard if you prepare and review the slide. The professor and TA are very nice.

Would recommand to CBB student with focus on Translational Informatics or Biomedical Data Science. For general CBB students who are not interested in any clinical aspect, I don't think this course is strongly necessary. But it is the required course anyway.
Yes. The course covers a great variety of topics and serves as a good introduction for students interested in this field.
For CBB students, it is super helpful since you can get an overview of different fields in biomedical data science.
